The Sahara Desert is not the largest desert in the world; it is the largest hot desert, but Antarctica is the largest overall.
Vikings did not wear horned helmets; this is a modern misconception popularized by 19th-century artistic depictions.
Chameleons do not change color to match their surroundings; they change color to communicate and regulate body temperature.
The Eiffel Tower is not the tallest structure in Paris; the Millau Viaduct is taller.
Meteors are not shooting stars; they are small pieces of space debris burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
The human body does not have 5 senses; it has many more, including balance, temperature, and proprioception.
Poinsettias are not poisonous; while they can cause mild irritation, they are not lethal to humans or pets.
Diamonds are not rare; they are artificially scarce due to market control by diamond companies.
Napoleon Bonaparte was not short; he was actually slightly above average height for his time.
Humans do not use only 10% of their brains; we use all of our brain, although not necessarily all at once.
The American Declaration of Independence was not signed on July 4th, 1776; it was approved on that date but signed later.
Sushi does not mean raw fish; it refers to the vinegared rice used in the dish, which may or may not include raw fish.
Coffee is not made from beans; it is made from the seeds of the coffee fruit, which are called coffee beans.
The forbidden fruit in the Garden of Eden was not an apple; the type of fruit is not specified in the Bible.
Frankenstein is not the name of the monster; it is the name of the scientist who created the monster.
The Mona Lisa does not have eyebrows; the painting shows no visible eyebrows, although they may have faded over time.
The word "jihad" does not always mean holy war; it can also refer to a personal spiritual struggle.
The Panama Canal does not run east to west; it actually runs north to south.
The Statue of Liberty is not located in New York City; it is located on Liberty Island, which is federal property.
The first Olympic Games were not held in Athens, Greece; they were held in Olympia, Greece.
The Tropic of Cancer does not pass through the United States; it passes through Mexico, the Bahamas, and several other countries.
The shortest war in history was not between Zanzibar and England; it was between Zanzibar and the United States.
The first person to reach the North Pole was not Robert Peary; it was likely Frederick Cook, although the claim is disputed.
The Wright brothers were not the first to fly a powered aircraft; they were the first to achieve controlled, sustained flight.
The Leaning Tower of Pisa is not the only leaning tower in Italy; there are several others, including the Leaning Tower of Burano.
The Bermuda Triangle is not a real phenomenon; the number of disappearances in the area is not significantly higher than in other parts of the ocean.
The Great Barrier Reef is not the largest living structure on Earth; it is the largest coral reef system, but there are larger living structures, such as fungal networks.
The Dead Sea is not the saltiest body of water on Earth; that distinction belongs to Don Juan Pond in Antarctica.
The Coriolis effect does not determine the direction of water flow in toilets; it is too weak to affect such small scales.
The Gregorian calendar is not used by all countries; some use the Julian, Hebrew, or Islamic calendars, among others.
The Fortune Cookie was not invented in China; it was invented in Japan and popularized in the United States by Chinese restaurants.
The world's largest desert is not the Sahara; it is Antarctica, which is considered a desert due to its low precipitation.
The Great Chicago Fire was not started by Mrs. O'Leary's cow; the true cause is unknown, but the cow story is a popular legend.
The Earth is not always the same distance from the Sun; its orbit is elliptical, bringing it closer and farther away throughout the year.
The Statue of Liberty is not made of solid copper; it is made of copper sheets mounted on a steel framework.
The Eiffel Tower is not painted; it is left in its natural metal color, which changes over time due to oxidation.
The Golden Gate Bridge is not painted gold; it is painted orange vermilion, which was chosen for its visibility in fog.
The Liberty Bell does not ring; it has been cracked since the early 19th century and is no longer rung to preserve it.
The Leaning Tower of Pisa is not the only building in Pisa that leans; the city's cathedral and baptistery also lean slightly.
The Parthenon is not the only building on the Acropolis; there are several other ancient Greek buildings on the site.
The Colosseum in Rome is not the largest amphitheater ever built; the Flavian Amphitheater in Capua was slightly larger.
The Taj Mahal is not a palace; it is a mausoleum built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan for his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
The Great Sphinx of Giza is not the oldest monument in Egypt; the Pyramid of Djoser is older by several hundred years.
The Mayan calendar did not predict the end of the world in 2012; it simply marked the end of a 5,126-year cycle.
The ancient Egyptians did not build the pyramids using slave labor; they were built by skilled workers who were well-fed and housed.
The Terracotta Army in China does not represent the entire army of the first emperor; it is a small fraction of the estimated 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots, and 670 horses.
The Hanging Gardens of Babylon were not located in Babylon; they were likely located in Nineveh, near present-day Mosul, Iraq.
The Great Wall of China is not a continuous wall; it is a series of walls and fortifications built over centuries by different dynasties.
The ancient city of Troy was not located in Greece; it was located in present-day Turkey.
The Nazca Lines in Peru were not created by aliens; they were created by the Nazca people between 500 BCE and 500 CE.
The Bermuda Triangle does not have a higher rate of disappearances than other areas of the ocean.
The dark side of the moon is not always dark; it receives sunlight during the moon's orbital cycle.
The sun is not yellow; it is actually white, but appears yellow due to Earth's atmosphere scattering blue light.
The North Star is not the brightest star in the night sky; it is Sirius, which is about 25 times more luminous.
The Milky Way is not the only galaxy in the universe; there are billions of other galaxies beyond our own.
Black holes do not suck in everything around them; their gravitational pull is strong, but not insurmountable.
The Big Bang was not an explosion in the conventional sense; it was a rapid expansion of space and time.
The asteroid belt is not a dense field of rocks; the asteroids are actually spread out over a vast area.
The Hubble Space Telescope is not the only space telescope; there are several others, including the James Webb Space Telescope.
The International Space Station is not the first space station; it was preceded by the Soviet Salyut and Mir stations.
The Moon is not the only natural satellite in our solar system; there are over 200 known moons orbiting other planets.
The planet Mercury is not always the closest planet to Earth; Venus can come closer at times due to its orbital path.
The Great Red Spot on Jupiter is not a solid surface feature; it is a massive, persistent storm in the planet's atmosphere.
The rings of Saturn are not solid; they are made up of countless ice particles, rocks, and dust.
The Kuiper Belt is not empty; it is a region of the solar system beyond Neptune that contains many small, icy objects.
The Oort Cloud is not a dense cloud; it is a theoretical shell of icy objects that surrounds the solar system at a great distance.
Pluto is not always the farthest planet from the Sun; its elliptical orbit sometimes brings it closer than Neptune.
The Sun does not orbit the Earth; the Earth orbits the Sun, along with the other planets in our solar system.
The Moon does not have a dark side; it has a far side that is not always visible from Earth due to tidal locking.
Mars is not always red; it can appear butterscotch or greenish in color depending on the presence of dust storms or seasonal changes.
Venus is not a habitable planet; its extremely high surface temperatures and pressures make it inhospitable to life as we know it.
The Andromeda Galaxy is not going to collide with the Milky Way; it will merge with our galaxy in about 4.5 billion years.
The Universe is not static; it is constantly expanding, with galaxies moving away from each other.
The Big Dipper is not a constellation; it is an asterism that is part of the larger constellation Ursa Major.
The North Pole is not located on land; it is located in the middle of the Arctic Ocean, usually covered by shifting sea ice.
The South Pole is not the coldest place on Earth; that distinction belongs to the Eastern Antarctic Plateau, where temperatures can drop below -90°C (-130°F).
The Mariana Trench is not the deepest part of the ocean; the Challenger Deep within the trench is the deepest known point.
The Gulf Stream is not a river; it is a warm ocean current that originates in the Gulf of Mexico and flows along the eastern coast of North America.
The Amazon River is not the longest river in the world; the Nile River is generally considered to be longer.
The Sahara Desert is not devoid of life; it is home to various plants, animals, and even some human populations.
Mount Everest is not the tallest mountain on Earth; Mauna Kea in Hawaii is taller when measured from its base on the ocean floor.
The Grand Canyon was not formed by a single event; it was carved over millions of years by the Colorado River and its tributaries.
The Dead Sea is not actually a sea; it is a hypersaline lake bordered by Jordan and Israel.
The Great Barrier Reef is not a single continuous structure; it is made up of over 2,900 individual reefs and 900 islands.
